column16: Constricted hood: pilocarpine activates the sphincter pupillae muscle to cause pupillary constriction (useful in acute angle-closure glaucoma)

column16: Wheezing man: cholinomimetics (e.g. methacholine) contract bronchial smooth muscle which may exacerbate asthma or COPD

column16: STIGMA: “-stigmine” drug suffix of acetylcholinesterase inhibitors

column16: Skeletal muscle brick wall: acetylcholinesterase inhibitors enhance effects of ACh at the NMJ (increase activity of NICOTINIC ACh receptors)

column9: Electrical end plate: motor endplate (at the NMJ)
column16: Electrical end plate: motor endplate (at the NMJ)

column16: GRAVIS graffiti: myasthenia gravis (MG)→ antibodies against nicotinic ACh receptors at motor endplate (skeletal muscle NMJ)

column16: Graffiti covering electrical end plates: MG causes progressive proximal weakness, ptosis, diplopia (inactivated nicotinic ACh receptors at motor endplate)

column16: Community PRIDE: PYRIDOstigmine (acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used as long-term treatment for MG)

column16: Removing graffiti on end plates: acetylcholinesterase inhibitors increase ACh at NMJ endplate to outcompete MG antibodies

column9: Neon sign STIGMA: neostigmine (acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used as treatment for MG)
column16: Neon sign STIGMA: neostigmine (acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used as treatment for MG)

column16: Phone booth: edrophonium (acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that transiently reverses symptoms of MG)

column16: Quarters only: pyridostigmine, neostigmine and edrophonium are quaternary amines and do not penetrate the CNS

column16: Phone in working order: edrophonium REVERSES muscle weakness in undertreated MG patients (POSITIVE tensilon test)

column16: Phone wire tension: tensilon test → edrophonium reverses (positive) or fails to reverse (negative) muscle weakness

column16: Phone out of order, with anti-esterase graffiti: edrophonium FAILS to reverse muscle weakness during cholinergic crisis (NEGATIVE tensilon test)

column16: CURARE crayons stuck in end plate: nondepolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents (e.g. tubocurarine, pancuronium, cisatracurium) inhibit nicotinic ACh receptors at NMJ endplate

column16: Neon sign store owner kicking out CURARE crayon kid: acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (e.g neostigmine) reverse nondepolarizing neuromuscular blockade

column16: SUCKS: succinylcholine is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent (nicotinic ACh receptor AGONIST)

column16: PHASE-1 cleanup crew getting shocked: initial PHASE-1 of depolarizing blockade is IRREVERSIBLE (acetylcholinesterase inhibitors potentiate blockade)

column16: Atropine in Wonderland: atropine overdose → “mad as a hatter, hot as a hare, blind as a bat” (reversed by physostigmine)

column16: Deadly nightshade: belladonna flower is a naturally occurring form of atropine (overdose reversed by physostigmine)

column9: GYM weeds: Jimson weed is a naturally occurring form of atropine (overdose reversed by physostigmine)

column16: PHYS ED teacher reprimanding atropine “artist”: physostigmine reverses atropine overdose (peripheral and CENTRAL effects)

column16: “Your brain on drugs”: physostigmine (and organophosphates) enters CNS to cause central cholinergic effects

column16: DUMBBELS: acetylcholinesterase inhibitor toxicity (Diarrhea, Urination, Miosis, Bronchospasm Bradycardia, Lacrimation, Salivation)

column16: Weak nicotine kid: acetylcholinesterase inhibitor toxicity includes flaccid paralysis (NMJ nicotinic ACh receptor over-activation)

column9: THIOL spray: insecticides (parathion, malathion, echothiophate) are organophosphates, a type of acetylcholinesterase inhibitor (also includes nerve agents and herbicides)
column16: THIOL spray: insecticides (parathion, malathion, echothiophate) are organophosphates, a type of acetylcholinesterase inhibitor (also includes nerve agents and herbicides)

column9: Green fumes: organophosphates are a major cause of acute cholinergic toxicity (DUMBBELS)
column16: Green fumes: organophosphates are a major cause of acute cholinergic toxicity (DUMBBELS)

column9: Closing LID on TOXIC spray: praLIDoxime reverses organophosphate toxicity (DUMBBELS)
column16: Closing LID on TOXIC spray: praLIDoxime reverses organophosphate toxicity (DUMBBELS)

column9: New toxic waste dumpsters: pralidoxime regenerates acetylcholinesterase at muscarinic and NICOTINIC receptors (reverses cholinergic toxicity INCLUDING FLACCID PARALYSIS)
column16: New toxic waste dumpsters: pralidoxime regenerates acetylcholinesterase at muscarinic and NICOTINIC receptors (reverses cholinergic toxicity INCLUDING FLACCID PARALYSIS)

column9: Atropine Alice is in your head: atropine reverses both peripheral and CENTRAL muscarinic toxicity from organophosphate poisoning (pralidoxime is peripheral only)
column16: Atropine Alice is in your head: atropine reverses both peripheral and CENTRAL muscarinic toxicity from organophosphate poisoning (pralidoxime is peripheral only)

column9: Old pest-control man: “aging” of the organophosphate-cholinesterase complex leads to irreversible binding
column16: Old pest-control man: “aging” of the organophosphate-cholinesterase complex leads to irreversible binding

column9: Corroded dumpster: pralidoxime is ineffective once aging of organophosphate- cholinesterase complex has occurred
column16: Corroded dumpster: pralidoxime is ineffective once aging of organophosphate- cholinesterase complex has occurred

column9: Alzheimer’s GALA: galantamine (acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used to treat Alzheimer’s disease)
column16: Alzheimer’s GALA: galantamine (acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used to treat Alzheimer’s disease)

column9: REVERSE the STIGMA: rivastigmine (acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used to treat Alzheimer’s disease)
column16: REVERSE the STIGMA: rivastigmine (acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used to treat Alzheimer’s disease)

column9: Done with brain puzzle: donepezil (acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used to treat Alzheimer’s disease)
column16: Done with brain puzzle: donepezil (acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used to treat Alzheimer’s disease)

column9: Brain puzzle: galantamine, rivastigmine, and donepezil penetrate the CNS
column16: Brain puzzle: galantamine, rivastigmine, and donepezil penetrate the CNS

column9: Motorcycle parking spots: muscarinic acetylcholine receptors (M1, M2, M3)
column16: Motorcycle parking spots: muscarinic acetylcholine receptors (M1, M2, M3)

column9: Reversing into motorcycle parking spot: muscarinic antagonists reversibly block muscarinic receptors
column16: Reversing into motorcycle parking spot: muscarinic antagonists reversibly block muscarinic receptors

column9: Blocked tweedleDUMBBELS: antimuscarinics block the muscarinic effects of diarrhea, urination, miosis, bronchospasm, bradycardia, lacrimation, salivation
column16: Blocked tweedleDUMBBELS: antimuscarinics block the muscarinic effects of diarrhea, urination, miosis, bronchospasm, bradycardia, lacrimation, salivation

column9: Blocked acetyl-cola bottle: antimuscarinics block the action of acetylcholine at M receptors
column16: Blocked acetyl-cola bottle: antimuscarinics block the action of acetylcholine at M receptors

column9: Alice: atropine (antimuscarinic)
column16: Alice: atropine (antimuscarinic)

column9: Belladonna flower - a natural antimuscarinic alkaloid
column16: Belladonna flower - a natural antimuscarinic alkaloid

column9: Jimson weed - a natural antimuscarinic alkaloid
column16: Jimson weed - a natural antimuscarinic alkaloid

column9: Large pupil gazing into the distance: antimuscarinics cause pupillary dilation (mydriasis) and cycloplegia (inability to accommodate the lens for near vision)
column16: Large pupil gazing into the distance: antimuscarinics cause pupillary dilation (mydriasis) and cycloplegia (inability to accommodate the lens for near vision)

column9: TeleSCOPE: scopolamine (antimuscarinic)
column16: TeleSCOPE: scopolamine (antimuscarinic)

column9: Seasick sailor outfit: scopolamine is used to treat motion sickness (vestibular nausea)
column16: Seasick sailor outfit: scopolamine is used to treat motion sickness (vestibular nausea)

column9: Eyepatch: scopolamine transdermal patch is used to treat motion sickness
column16: Eyepatch: scopolamine transdermal patch is used to treat motion sickness

column9: CNS hat: antimuscarinics (e.g. scopolamine) cross the blood-brain barrier and inhibits central M1 receptors
column16: CNS hat: antimuscarinics (e.g. scopolamine) cross the blood-brain barrier and inhibits central M1 receptors

column9: Heart with jewel nodes: antimuscarinics block parasympathetic activation of M2 receptors on the SA and AV nodes (increased heart rate, increased AV conduction)
column16: Heart with jewel nodes: antimuscarinics block parasympathetic activation of M2 receptors on the SA and AV nodes (increased heart rate, increased AV conduction)

column9: Elevated heart watch: antimuscarinics (e.g. atropine) increase heart rate (useful in the treatment of bradycardia)
column16: Elevated heart watch: antimuscarinics (e.g. atropine) increase heart rate (useful in the treatment of bradycardia)

column9: Heart shield: heart block (atrioventricular block)
column16: Heart shield: heart block (atrioventricular block)

column9: Falling heart shields: antimuscarinics (e.g. atropine) increase AV conduction (useful in the treatment of heart block)
column16: Falling heart shields: antimuscarinics (e.g. atropine) increase AV conduction (useful in the treatment of heart block)

column9: Cat-ipra-tio-tropillar: ipratropium and tiotropium (M3 muscarinic antagonists)
column16: Cat-ipra-tio-tropillar: ipratropium and tiotropium (M3 muscarinic antagonists)

column9: Puffing: ipratropium and tiotropium are inhaled antimuscarinic bronchodilators
column16: Puffing: ipratropium and tiotropium are inhaled antimuscarinic bronchodilators

column9: Blue bloater with pink puffer: ipratropium and tiotropium are useful in the management of COPD (antagonize M3 receptors → bronchodilation, decreased secretions)
column16: Blue bloater with pink puffer: ipratropium and tiotropium are useful in the management of COPD (antagonize M3 receptors → bronchodilation, decreased secretions)

column9: Long lasting TIO smoke rings: tiotropium dissociates more slowly from the M3 receptor (longer bronchodilator action)
column16: Long lasting TIO smoke rings: tiotropium dissociates more slowly from the M3 receptor (longer bronchodilator action)

column9: Ox butler: oxybutynin (M3 muscarinic antagonist)
column16: Ox butler: oxybutynin (M3 muscarinic antagonist)

column9: Turning off bladder: oxybutynin and tolterodine treat incontinence (antagonize M3 receptors → relax smooth muscle in ureters and bladder wall)
column16: Turning off bladder: oxybutynin and tolterodine treat incontinence (antagonize M3 receptors → relax smooth muscle in ureters and bladder wall)

column9: Turtle butler: tolterodine (M3 muscarinic antagonist)
column16: Turtle butler: tolterodine (M3 muscarinic antagonist)

column9: CENTER over M1: M1 muscarinic receptors are found in the CNS
column16: CENTER over M1: M1 muscarinic receptors are found in the CNS

column9: PARKING over M1: M1 receptor antagonists can reduce tremors and rigidity in Parkinson’s disease
column16: PARKING over M1: M1 receptor antagonists can reduce tremors and rigidity in Parkinson’s disease

column9: Benz parked in M1: benztropine (centrally acting M1 muscarinic antagonist)
column16: Benz parked in M1: benztropine (centrally acting M1 muscarinic antagonist)

column9: Tri-hex car parked in M1: trihexyphenidyl (centrally acting M1 muscarinic antagonist)
column16: Tri-hex car parked in M1: trihexyphenidyl (centrally acting M1 muscarinic antagonist)

column9: Shaking antenna: centrally acting antimuscarinics (e.g. benztropine, trihexyphenidyl) treat tremor and rigidity in Parkinson’s (block excess cholinergic activity)
column16: Shaking antenna: centrally acting antimuscarinics (e.g. benztropine, trihexyphenidyl) treat tremor and rigidity in Parkinson’s (block excess cholinergic activity)

column9: Cogwheel: excessive M1 activation is associated with cogwheel rigidity in Parkinson’s disease
column16: Cogwheel: excessive M1 activation is associated with cogwheel rigidity in Parkinson’s disease

column9: Falling “extra parking” cone: antimuscarinics treat extrapyramidal side effects caused by antipsychotics: e.g. dystonia, akathisia, parkinsonism (re-establish dopaminergic- cholinergic balance)
column16: Falling “extra parking” cone: antimuscarinics treat extrapyramidal side effects caused by antipsychotics: e.g. dystonia, akathisia, parkinsonism (re-establish dopaminergic- cholinergic balance)

column9: Hot as a hare: antimuscarinics inhibit M3 receptors on sweat glands → decreased sweating → hyperthermia
column16: Hot as a hare: antimuscarinics inhibit M3 receptors on sweat glands → decreased sweating → hyperthermia

column9: Dry as a cracker: antimuscarinics decrease salivation and lacrimation → dry mouth and eyes
column16: Dry as a cracker: antimuscarinics decrease salivation and lacrimation → dry mouth and eyes

column9: Blind as a bat: antimuscarinics cause mydriasis and cycloplegia→ blurred vision
column16: Blind as a bat: antimuscarinics cause mydriasis and cycloplegia→ blurred vision

column9: High-pressure as a kettle: antimuscarinics cause mydriasis → decreased outflow of aqueous humor → acute angle closure glaucoma
column16: High-pressure as a kettle: antimuscarinics cause mydriasis → decreased outflow of aqueous humor → acute angle closure glaucoma

column9: Mad as a hatter: antimuscarinics cross the BBB and antagonize central M1 receptors → sedation, agitation, hallucination, coma (especially in elderly patients)
column16: Mad as a hatter: antimuscarinics cross the BBB and antagonize central M1 receptors → sedation, agitation, hallucination, coma (especially in elderly patients)
